Document Sources.Sourced Statement: “We were dismayed to learn that our small, rural county was among the top three destinations in the state where people experiencing homelessness were sent by the program,” states a draft of the letter to San Francisco Mayor London Breed that can be seen on the Humboldt County website.
Document Sources.Source Justification: a draft of the letter to San Francisco Mayor London Breed that can be seen on the Humboldt County website

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: “We are concerned that providing bus tickets to other jurisdictions without verifying access to housing, family support or employment does not alleviate homelessness; it simply shifts the person to another county,” Humboldt’s letter says.
“We urge you to ensure that Journey Home participants have the support they need to obtain housing and employment before they receive transportation assistance to Humboldt County.
Let’s act together in partnership to alleviate homelessness throughout our state.”

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Paul Boden, a homeless advocate with the Western Regional Advocacy Project, said the strategy of busing unhoused people out of town dates back to the 1960s, when welfare agencies offered bus tickets to previously institutionalized people in exchange for a signed pledge not to return for a year — a process that was known as “Greyhound therapy.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The aim isn’t to achieve a goal.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: It’s to get you out of our town, and it’s cheaper than arresting you,” Boden said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “The No. 1 answer to homelessness is to make them disappear.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Then mayors write letters back and forth: ‘Stop sending your people here.’
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Then it turns out they’re sending their people here.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: It shows the ridiculousness of us not trying to address why people are on the streets.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: with the Western Regional Advocacy Project

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Our TAP program works really well, and hopefully San Francisco can go back to more — not just dumping — but assisting and actually helping people get help,” Humboldt Supervisor Rex Bohn said at Tuesday’s board meeting.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: Los Angeles and Sacramento counties are the two other most popular California destinations, according to SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency.
Named Organization Sources.Name of Source: SF’s Department of Homelessness and Supportive Housing and the Human Services Agency

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: When asked for comment, the San Francisco mayor’s office said it had not received the letter.
